docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Lisa Landi was diagnosed with full-blown AIDS in 1991, she weighed 80 pounds and was not expected to live. Today, thanks to protease inhibitor drugs, Ms. Landi, 33, is healthy enough to work part time, and to have other concerns -- like what to do now that her company has gone out of business. ''When I planned on dying, I'd catch the sunrise every day as if it were my last,'' said Ms. Landi, who moved from West Islip to Queens after the AIDS was diagnosed. ''Work wasn't an issue, because if you're going to be dead, what's the point? But now that I've become human again, there are everyday things on my mind like my health insurance, and I'm too busy worrying to catch the sunrise anymore.''

headline.main: Longer Lives With AIDS Mean Facing New Worries

docs.abstract: Article on problems and worries that many of Long Island's AIDS patients must face now that they have been freed from death sentences as result of protease drugs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Along with the concerns raised in ''For the Uninsured, Drug Trials Are Health Care'' (front page, June 22), additional problems result from the practice of encouraging uninsured patients to enroll in drug trials.

headline.main: When Drug Trials Equal Health Care

docs.abstract: Martin Schiffenbauer letter warns that encouraging uninsured patients to enroll in drug trials may skew tests results (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Along with the concerns raised in ''For the Uninsured, Drug Trials Are Health Care'' (front page, June 22), additional problems result from the practice of encouraging uninsured patients to enroll in drug trials.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''For the Uninsured, Drug Trials Are Health Care'' (front page, June 22): As a participant in my second clinical trial -- and an advocate for affordable health care -- I would like to stress that not only can you often get access to better doctors and treatments in a clinical trial, plus travel expenses, but by doing a little research, you can get very advanced treatments sometimes years before they are available. And you still have a pretty good idea what you are getting into.

headline.main: When Drug Trials Equal Health Care

docs.abstract: Bonnie Burke letter explains that she participates in drug trials and gets access to better doctors and treatment than would be possible for her otherwise (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It matters little whether people who participate in drug trials are insured or uninsured (front page, June 22). Not only is it a form of health care, it is exemplary personalized health care even for the individual with the best form of private health insurance. Each patient is assigned to a coordinator, who is usually a registered nurse working closely with a physician.

headline.main: When Drug Trials Equal Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Two-year-old Bryana Gammel's rosebud lips gaped open, held by a retractor, to reveal baby teeth that were rotted down to the gum line. Her long lashes lay against her cheeks in the forced sleep of anesthesia. One by one, Dr. Jay Afrow's delicate forceps gripped, wiggled and wrenched out the decay-stained teeth, until they lay, like tiny arrowheads, on a surgical tray. Six of them.

headline.main: Many Dentists Won't Fix Poor Children's Bad Teeth

docs.abstract: Millions of poor American children are receiving inadequate or no dental care despite fact that vast majority of poorest Americans, particularly children, are covered by Medicaid for dental care; experts say many dentists are reluctant to take patients on Medicaid, state-run health insurance for poor and disabled, because program tends to scrimp on payments and involves pencil-breaking bureaucracy; also Medicaid patients are much likelier to miss appointments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a news conference today by President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency: Prepared Remarks Earlier today, in a speech at Georgetown University, I discussed the opportunities now before our nation. Before I take questions, let me just take a moment to recap what I believe is America's agenda in the coming months.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nasdaq and S.& P. Decline; Dow Jones Rises 17 Points The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.34 points, to 2,552.65, as trading was slow and investors awaited the meeting Tuesday and Wednesday of the Federal Open Market Committee. Investors expect the Federal Reserve's policy-making panel to raise short-term interest rates a quarter percentage point to head off inflation. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.47 point, to 1,315.31, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.73 points, to 10,552.56. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond declined to 6.15 percent from 6.16 percent on Thursday. [Page C3.] Economy Growing at a 4.3% Rate Torrid consumer spending helped the gross domestic product -- the nation's output of goods and services -- grow at a brisk annual rate of 4.3 percent in the first quarter of the year, the Commerce Department reported. [C4.] Priests Say They Were Duped In Rome, two priests, the Rev. Peter Jacobs, 73, an American, and Monsignor Emilio Colagiovanni, 79, a scholarly Italian, provided a clerical cloak of respectability for a money manager who authorities suspect embezzled more than $300 million from American insurance companies. Both men insist they were duped by Martin R. Frankel, who disappeared last month and is wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. [A1.] Campbell Earnings to Fall Short Campbell Soup said that earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter would fall 8 cents to 10 cents a share below analysts' forecasts of 38 cents a share and that it planned to reorganize its soup operations. Mark M. Leckie, the president of the company's domestic soup division, will leave the company. He will be succeeded at the new North American division by F. Martin Thrasher, now the company's president of European and Canadian operations. [C4.] Nissan's Western-Style Meeting In Japan, where annual shareholders' meetings, are traditionally closed affairs, Nissan Motor moved to Western-style openness, allowing news coverage. But the reward for the troubled company's president, Yoshikazu Hanawa, left, was a scolding gadfly shareholder who identified himself only as Mr. Tamura and demanded his resignation, saying, ''You've made mistake after mistake.'' Next Tuesday, 1,374 companies, or 88 percent of Japan's listed companies, are to hold their meetings. [C2.] Latin-European Trade Meeting Set Seeking to increase trade and gain a counterweight to American global economic dominance, leaders of Latin America and Europe, the world's second- and third-largest trading blocs, are to meet in Rio de Janeiro this weekend and early next week. Their summit meeting, their first, has already proved contentious on several basic issues, notably French insistence that farm products be excluded from any free-trade pact. [C2.] In Indonesia, a Step Toward Health In Indonesia, the agreement this week between PT Astra International and its creditors on how the big company, which assembles Toyota utility vehicles and Honda motorcycles, will pay back more than $1 billion in debt is being heralded as evidence that the nation is on the mend. But Indonesia is by no means well. [C2.] BBC's New Head Stirs Controversy The British Broadcasting Corporation stirred passionate debate by appointing as its new head Greg Dyke, a millionaire Labor Party supporter associated with ''Baywatch'' and a puppet called Roland Rat. He has been head of Pearson Television, but the Conservative opposition focused on his Labor ties. [A3.] Covance and Parexel Halt Merger Covance and Parexel International, two drug-development companies, called off their planned merger, originally valued at more than $600 million. [C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton challenged Republicans today to work with him on domestic legislation so ''this summer should be a season of progress,'' but made clear that he was just as willing to blame them for failure as to share credit for success. In a speech at Georgetown University and in a news conference later, Mr. Clinton identified four bills as available for quick action because of broad bipartisan agreement. But one, campaign finance legislation, is strongly opposed by Republican leaders, and a second, the so-called patient's bill of rights, has Democrats seeking very broad application and a right to sue health maintenance organizations, two features opposed by most Republicans.

headline.main: Clinton Prods Congress Over a Four-Bill Package

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton challenges Republicans to work with him on domestic legislation, speech, Georgetown University, and later news conference; indicates he is willing to blame them for failure or share credit for success; cites four bills available for quick action because of broad bipartisan support; one bill, campaign finance reform, is strongly opposed by Republican leaders; another, patient's bill of rights, contains features opposed by most Republicans; Republican leaders seem ready to accept bills to let disabled people returning to work retain Federal health benefits and to raise minimum wage; Republican Chmn Jim Nicholson charges Clinton passes up chance to work for real bipartisan solutions; photo (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare officials said today that they had told the White House that its initial hope of offering coverage of prescription drugs for a premium of no more than $25 a month was unrealistic. At the same time, House Democrats said they had become nervous about the plan being drafted by President Clinton to revamp Medicare, because they feared that the prospect of higher premiums could alarm elderly voters.

docs.lead_paragraph: The weekly managers' meetings at the Family Physicians Group, a private practice here, almost always include a lot of angry discussion about the increasing frustrations of dealing with health maintenance organizations and other managed-care insurance companies. But at this morning's meeting, the anger was tempered by hope, said Dr. Charles J. Woodall, the group's medical director, in light of the American Medical Association's decision on Wednesday to form a union for doctors.

headline.main: Some Doctors See Relief In Plan for A.M.A. Union

docs.abstract: Some doctors laud American Medical Assn's decision to form union for doctors, reflecting their increasing frustrations of dealing with health maintenance organizations and other managed-care insurance companies; contend doctors have long been hamstrung by managed-care regulations that require needless procedures and do not cover useful procedures (M)
